Del: Bob Marshall's statement: The expert's verdict mentions that Del. Bob Marshall made the claim about homosexual behavior cutting one's life by about 20 years. This is the initial aspect that was employed to verify the authenticity of the claim.
Citing a study: Marshall provided an email citing a study published in June 1997 in the International Journal of Epidemiology. The study examined the impact of HIV on the mortality of gay and bisexual men in Vancouver from 1987 to 1992. This study is another aspect that was used to verify the claim.
Life expectancy deficit: The study found that life expectancy at age 20 among gay and bisexual men in Vancouver was 8 to 21 years shorter than that of all men in the Canadian city. This life expectancy deficit is a crucial aspect that supports Marshall's claim.
Researchers: statement: The report's authors, in 2001, mentioned that if they were to repeat the analysis at that time, the life expectancy of gay and bisexual men would be greatly improved. They noted that deaths from HIV infection had declined dramatically in this population since 1996. This statement from the researchers is another aspect that was considered to verify the authenticity of the claim.
